liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: By Holly Richardson Two Russians and a French citizen have been rescued from the Coral Sea, 835 kilometres, south-east of Cairns, after their inflatable catamaran began sinking. The nine-metre boat was on its way from Vanuatu to Cairns when both hulls were damaged in several shark attacks. The group activated an emergency beacon at 1:30am, and the Australian Maritime Safety Authority requested the assistance of a nearby vehicle carrier along with the Cairns-based Challenger Rescue Aircraft. The vehicle carrier, Dugong Ace, collected the group. They are due to arrive in Brisbane on Thursday.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Three people rescued after inflatable boat attacked by sharks in Coral Sea

children.content: By Holly Richardson

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: By Patrick Bell Federal ministers are adamant there is no need for a review of the government's decision to reject Qatar Airways' application for more flights to major Australian airports. That is despite the Senate voting to hold an inquiry into the decision, and revelations the prime minister was unaware exactly when Transport Minister Catherine King signed off on the decision. In Question Time yesterday, Anthony Albanese said he had spoken to Virgin Australia CEO Jayne Hrdlicka, whose airline codeshares with Qatar, before the application was rejected, but insisted he did not have a conversation with former Qantas CEO Alan Joyce. You can read the rest of the story below.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Federal government has 'no intention' to review Qatar Airways decision

featuredLink.title: 'No intention' to review Qatar Airways decision despite Senate inquiry

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: As we reported earlier, the bill to extend the deadline for the $13 billion Murray-Darling Basin Plan will be put before Parliament today. Environment Minister Tanya Plibersek told News Breakfast she's "very hopeful" the legislation introduced today will pass the Senate. "We have got things here that both the Nationals and Liberals and Greens have been calling for. What this plan offers is a rescue of the Murray-Darling Basin Plan with more time, more funding, more options, and more accountability. "We know we need more time to deliver the plan because so little has been achieved in the last 10 years."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Plibersek 'very hopeful' Murray-Darling Basin bill will pass Senate

children.content: As we reported earlier, the bill to extend the deadline for the $13 billion Murray-Darling Basin Plan will be put before Parliament today.
(ABC News)
Environment Minister
Tanya Plibersek
told
News Breakfast
she's "very hopeful" the legislation introduced today will pass the Senate.

"We have got things here that both the Nationals and Liberals and Greens have been calling for. What this plan offers is a rescue of the Murray-Darling Basin Plan with more time, more funding, more options, and more accountability.
"We know we need more time to deliver the plan because so little has been achieved in the last 10 years."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Financial firm Macquarie Group has told investors that its first quarter profit from its annuity business is "substantially down" compared to the same time last year because of weaker trading conditions. The company says this was driven by lower investment related income from green energy investments. The markets business was hit by lower commodity prices, and reduced trading activity across gas and power. Macquarie's net profit rose 10 per cent for the 2023 financial year to $5.2 billion.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Macquarie says quarterly profit is weaker

children.content: Financial firm
Macquarie Group
has told investors that its first quarter profit from its annuity business is
"substantially down"
compared to the same time last year because of weaker trading conditions.
The company says this was driven by lower investment related income from green energy investments.
The markets business was hit by lower commodity prices, and reduced trading activity across gas and power.
Macquarie's net profit rose 10 per cent for the 2023 financial year to $5.2 billion.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Yesterday the New South Wales government said it would engage with Origin Energy about extending the life of the Eraring power station, which is slated to close in August 2025. That's after a review of the state's energy transition recommended the government discuss delaying the closure because of concerns about as shortfall in electricity supply. NSW Premier Chris Minns has told ABC News Breakfast that it's too early to say the cost to taxpayers to keep the plant open for longer. "This is a really narrow and tricky path to follow. I can't give you a quantum or amount that will be paid to Eraring because those commercial discussions have only just begun or will be about to begin." Former NSW Energy Minister Matt Kean has claimed it could cost up to $1 billion a year to keep Eraring open. But according to documents filed with the NSW Parliament, Origin Energy told the former NSW government in July 2021 that keeping the ageing plant partially open would cost taxpayers about $70 million a year. Origin said the plant was a "bottomless pit" and its preference was to close the plant by the middle of the decade. "Eraring is loss-making now, and we expect that to worsen over the decade, even with careful cost management," Origin said in a presentation to the government in July 2021. Here's more from energy reporter Dan Mercer and Kit Mochan.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Origin Energy called Eraring power plant a "bottomless pit"

featuredLink.title: 'Low cost' or 'bottomless pit'? Secret documents detail failed efforts to rescue huge coal plant

children.content: Yesterday the New South Wales government said it would engage with Origin Energy about extending the life of the Eraring power station, which is slated to close in August 2025.
That's after a review of the state's energy transition recommended the government discuss delaying the closure because of concerns about as shortfall in electricity supply.
NSW Premier Chris Minns has told ABC News Breakfast that it's too early to say the cost to taxpayers to keep the plant open for longer.

"This is a really narrow and tricky path to follow. I can't give you a quantum or amount that will be paid to Eraring because those commercial discussions have only just begun or will be about to begin."
Former NSW Energy Minister Matt Kean has claimed it could cost up to $1 billion a year to keep Eraring open.

But according to documents filed with the NSW Parliament, Origin Energy told the former NSW government in July 2021 that keeping the ageing plant partially open would cost taxpayers about $70 million a year.
Origin said the plant was a "bottomless pit" and its preference was to close the plant by the middle of the decade.
"Eraring is loss-making now, and we expect that to worsen over the decade, even with careful cost management," Origin said in a presentation to the government in July 2021.
Here's more from energy reporter Dan Mercer and Kit Mochan.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A Senate inquiry will examine the federal government's decision to block Qatar Airways from increasing its flights into major capital cities. The decision is at the heart of a political storm with the government accused of protecting Qantas, with critics saying that allowing more international flights will reduce airfares. Senators voted 32 to 31 to establish an inquiry examining the impacts of the Qatar Airways decision, including the cost of flights. But Treasurer Jim Chalmers has told RN Breakfast that the government has no intention of reviewing the decision, and the "decision was the right one, taken in the usual way." "The aviation sector is expanding, international flights are expanding and what I'm trying to tell you is that different transport ministers, not just Minister King (Catherine King), Minister McCormack under the other government, from time to time decisions are taken not to proceed with these kind of outcomes between countries." "It's not actually that unusual." Shadow transport minister Brigid McKenzie says the inquiry will examine why the decision was made. "I think it's been clear over the last couple of weeks in particular that Australians have a lot of questions about why this government keeps making decisions that keep airfares high and cancellations and delays in the wrong direction." Meanwhile, it was a dramatic day yesterday with Qantas boss Alan Joyce stepping down early, replaced by Vanessa Hudson who has pledged to put customers first. Here's more from my colleagues Kate Ainsworth and Nassim Khadem.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Treasurer says no review of Qatar Airways decision

featuredLink.title: New Qantas CEO Vanessa Hudson faces an uphill battle to restore the public's faith as Alan Joyce departs

children.content: A Senate inquiry will examine the federal government's decision to block Qatar Airways from increasing its flights into major capital cities.
The decision is at the heart of a political storm with the government accused of protecting Qantas, with critics saying that allowing more international flights will reduce airfares.
Senators voted 32 to 31 to establish an inquiry examining the impacts of the Qatar Airways decision, including the cost of flights.
But Treasurer Jim Chalmers has told RN Breakfast that the government has no intention of reviewing the decision, and the "decision was the right one, taken in the usual way."

"The aviation sector is expanding, international flights are expanding and what I'm trying to tell you is that different transport ministers, not just Minister King (Catherine King), Minister McCormack under the other government, from time to time decisions are taken not to proceed with these kind of outcomes between countries."
"It's not actually that unusual."
Shadow transport minister Brigid McKenzie says the inquiry will examine why the decision was made.

"I think it's been clear over the last couple of weeks in particular that Australians have a lot of questions about why this government keeps making decisions that keep airfares high and cancellations and delays in the wrong direction."
Meanwhile, it was a dramatic day yesterday with Qantas boss Alan Joyce stepping down early, replaced by Vanessa Hudson who has pledged to put customers first.
Here's more from my colleagues Kate Ainsworth and Nassim Khadem.
